ControlDescription:
Enable Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) capabilities for VMs and integrate with SIEM and security operations processes.

Microsoft Defender for servers (with Microsoft Defender for Endpoint integrated) provides EDR capability to prevent, detect, investigate, and respond to advanced threats.

Use Microsoft Defender for Cloud to deploy Microsoft Defender for servers on your endpoints and integrate the alerts to your SIEM solution such as Microsoft Sentinel.
Question:
1. Are all Azure VMs onboarded to Microsoft Defender for Servers (with Defender for Endpoint)?
2. Are EDR alerts integrated into Microsoft Sentinel or SIEM for investigation?
3. Is coverage monitored to ensure no VM or server is excluded from EDR deployment?
RequiredEvidence:
1. Defender for Cloud "EDR coverage" compliance report ( az security assessment list -- query "[?name == 'microsoft.security/edrMonitoring']" ).
2. List of onboarded machines in Microsoft Defender for Endpoint ( Get-MpComputerStatus or Defender API export).
3. Microsoft Sentinel connector configuration logs showing Defender for Endpoint integration.
EvidenceItems: Defender for Cloud "EDR coverage" compliance report ( az security assessment list -- query "[?name == 'microsoft.security/edrMonitoring']" ) | List of onboarded machines in Microsoft Defender for Endpoint ( Get-MpComputerStatus or Defender API export) | Microsoft Sentinel connector configuration logs showing Defender for Endpoint integration

ControlDescription:
Use anti-malware solutions (also known as endpoint protection) capable of real-time protection and periodic scanning.

Microsoft Defender for Cloud can automatically identify the use of a number of popular anti-malware solutions for your virtual machines and on-premises machines with Azure Arc configured and report the endpoint protection running status and make recommendations.

Microsoft Defender Antivirus is the default anti-malware solution for Windows server 2016 and above. For Windows server 2012 R2, use Microsoft Antimalware extension to enable SCEP (System Center Endpoint Protection). For Linux VMs, use Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on Linux for the endpoint protection feature.

For both Windows and Linux, you can use Microsoft Defender for Cloud to discover and assess the health status of the anti-malware solution.
Question:
1. Is Microsoft Defender Antivirus (Windows) or Defender for Endpoint (Linux) enabled on all VMs?
2. Are third-party anti-malware solutions detected and health-monitored in Defender for Cloud?
3. Are periodic scans and real-time protection enabled across all workloads?
RequiredEvidence:
1. Defender for Cloud "Endpoint Protection Not Installed/Not Healthy" recommendations ( az security assessment-metadata list -- query "[?contains(name, 'endpoint')]" ).
2. VM extension status for Microsoft Antimalware ( az vm extension list -- name IaaS Antimalware ).
3. Anti-malware health logs from Log Analytics workspace ( Heartbeat | where Solution contains "Antimalware" ).
EvidenceItems: Defender for Cloud "Endpoint Protection Not Installed/Not Healthy" recommendations ( az security assessment-metadata list -- query "[?contains(name, 'endpoint')]" ) | VM extension status for Microsoft Antimalware ( az vm extension list -- name IaaS Antimalware ) | Anti-malware health logs from Log Analytics workspace ( Heartbeat | where Solution contains "Antimalware" )

ControlTitle: Ensure anti-malware software and signatures are updated
ControlDescription:
Ensure anti-malware signatures are updated rapidly and consistently for the anti-malware solution.

Follow recommendations in Microsoft Defender for Cloud to keep all endpoints up to date with the latest signatures. Microsoft Antimalware (for Windows) and Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (for Linux) will automatically install the latest signatures and engine updates by default.

For third-party solutions, ensure the signatures are updated in the third-party anti-malware solution.
Question:
1. Are malware signatures automatically updated on all Windows/Linux endpoints?
2. Are update failures (out-of-date signatures) flagged in Defender for Cloud?
3. Are signature update events logged and auditable for compliance?
RequiredEvidence:
1. Defender for Cloud assessment for "Endpoint protection should be up-to-date" ( az security assessment list -- query "[?name == 'microsoft.security/antimalwareUpToDate']" ).
2. Windows update logs ( Get-MpSignature for Defender AV).
3. Linux signature status logs ( mdatp health -- field definitions_updated ).
4. Log Analytics query on update events ( SecurityBaseline | where RecommendationName contains 'Antimalware signature' ).
